title: Improve compiler error for missing Clone trait bound

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

body:
I just faced a compiler error when trying to clone a hashmap parameterized by a non-clone type. The error was a bit cryptic, about not expecting a reference, until I realized I've forgot to add the `T: Clone` trait bound. Here is a minimal function reproducing my issue:
```rust
fn clone_map<T>(map1: &HashMap<String, T>) -> HashMap<String, T> {
    map1.clone()
}
```
And here is the error I got:
```
7 | fn clone_map<T>(map1: &HashMap<String, T>) -> HashMap<String, T> {
  |                                               ------------------ expected `std::collections::HashMap<std::string::String, T>` because of return type
8 |     map1.clone()
  |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^ expected struct `std::collections::HashMap`, found reference
  |
  = note: expected struct `std::collections::HashMap<std::string::String, T>`
          found reference `&std::collections::HashMap<std::string::String, T>`
```
The code is available [in the playground here](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=23cdc202bd5538dba1afe3d98ba63ce8). I was wondering if the compiler could deduce that the mistake here could be a missing trait bound and give that hint to the developer.
